body: **Thumbs up üëç this comment if you would want to be able to work on spreadsheets from within neovim seamlessly/natively. Consider watching sc-im [screencast](https://youtu.be/K_8_gazN7h0) I reference at the bottom of this comment to see where it could begin, and the potential it already has. That has been suggested below as a way to poll neovim users for interest in this feature, and make your voice heard to neovim dev team.** [sc-im](https://github.com/andmarti1424/sc-im) is the improved/improvised version of [sc](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sc_(spreadsheet_calculator)) spreadsheet calculator program based on vim bindings, vim modal behavior (normal, visual, insert, command). It's script looks like Vimscript, and it integrates with Lua 5.1 (one can manipulate entire spreadsheet from Lua side). The project seems to be a lone person's project, and might benefit from the sponsorship, support, and C+Lua expertise that neovim has. Here are some screenshots, and links to videos: 1) A spreadsheet for converting 0-255 color range of RGB to 0-1000 color range of ncursesw's RGB for [Dracula theme](https://draculatheme.com). Cells in magenta are expressions that sc-im evaluated. One can write an expression once, and yank it (using yy), then enter visual (block) mode mode (entered by simply pressing v in normal mode) and select cells by pressing h/j/k/l or arrow keys, and finally paste the expression by pressing p. 2) Startup screen: 3) Screencast that shows some basic features: https://youtu.be/K_8_gazN7h0 Thanks!

comment_data.body: This seems like it would make an excellent plugin? I don't think it's a fit for core though.

@mjlbach Excellent plug-out maybe, it works well in its own right as a ncurses based external CLI utility, and maybe maintains that possibility. Having this under the umbrella of neovim's team would bring about the best synergistic result I think. On one hand it will add immense value to neovim (to edit & operate on tabular data), and on the other hand it will support the program itself in long run. I have been using it since last two days, and for the very first time in my life I am loving the process of  making new spreadsheets. It needs some bug fixes, and improvements though. The Lua side for expressions and controlling the results seems more solid (I had only one [glitch](https://github.com/andmarti1424/sc-im/issues/496) so far), their vim-script side seems to have more bug (like the one [bug](https://github.com/andmarti1424/sc-im/issues/497) I field yesterday). I think they need more C side expertise, and it would make sense to just have one vim-script (instead of them having their own flavor), and common integration with Lua. It is very fast though, unlike a very basic csv plugin written in vimscript: https://github.com/chrisbra/csv.vim

I don't see the value in the two benefits you mention:

>On one hand it will add immense value to neovim (to edit & operate on tabular data)

I don't see value in this. I rarely edit tabular data and when I do, neovim is enough for my uses. I would wager that this is the situation the majority of Neovim users are in.
I also do not see what is preventing the minority of Neovim users who do edit tabular data frequently and need more that what Neovim can offer from just installing sc-im.

>and on the other hand it will support the program itself in long run

This would be a good thing for sc-im, but this doesn't bring anything to Neovim. Moreover, there is nothing preventing current Neovim contributors from contributing to sc-im as a separate project if they so desire.

@glacambre In my engineering field, there are jobs where spreadsheet is an indispensable second task after designing and coding for engineers. I see a lot of value that this can add to neovim, as structured text like like in csv format is text that we work on. The current attempts at adding csv plugin (https://github.com/chrisbra/csv.vim) support to vim/neovim is a duplicate effort (not to mention the serious limitations), and getting this in can help save effort duplication while brining the most value. The similarity with vim in UI at every level, and it's own "vimscript" should not be neglected. In long run, having one unified application interface way for working with both source code files, and structured data makes sense.

The other places where this can help with is visualizing & efficiently manipulating other structured data formats, all with a unified interface. And neovim need not have separate plugins for each of those. Well, having it associated with neovim will ensure more exposure of sc-im to potential developers. "This would be a good thing for sc-im, but this doesn't bring anything to Neovim.", not if we can think of innovative ways to integrate it, and then start loving to use the pleasurable interface we create. Am not a C developer, but can offer some sponsorship for the development.

>In my engineering field, there are jobs where spreadsheet is an indispensable second task after designing and coding for engineers.

Ok, but what about the majority of Neovim users? I am willing to bet that the majority of Neovim users do not need this. The benefit/effort ratio is thus very low.

>The current attempts at adding csv plugin (https://github.com/chrisbra/csv.vim) support to vim/neovim is a duplicate effort (not to mention the serious limitations)

This plugin is mostly a personal project of chrisbra, AFAICT no neovim devs have spent any time or effort on it. It is thus not a duplicate effort and if you want Chrisbra to contribute to sc-im/take ideas from it, you should ask him directly :).

I would recommend you either implement or hire somebody to implement your ideas and then show us how useful bringing sc-im and neovim together would be for the majority of Neovim users. Once the usefulness of your ideas have been proven, I'm sure neovim maintainers will not hesitate to integrate them in Neovim.

For now neovim core should focus on the API:s needed to implement similar functionality as plugins (more display decorations, structured text, etc etc).

Does sc-im have a remote API or something? Then you could write a plugin that embeds sc-im in a terminal and communicates with it. :)

@glacambre Is there a way to poll neovim users? rather than betting on our preferences? Also, I never claimed chrisbra's plugin is official neovim plugin, or that any neovim devs have spent time on it. I understand where you are coming from, would like to hear rest of the neovim user base.

>Is there a way to poll neovim users?

You could ask people to add a thumb-up/thumb-down reaction to the issue, spread the word on the neovim gitter/irc/matrix channel and ask people on Reddit.
@mjlbach hence the "embed in :terminal" part. I meant more side-channel API communication (like sending values to scim-script or whatever integration users expect).

@bfredl Yes @mjlbach is correct. There is no remote API. The closest thing in it is: one can get and set the contents of any of the cells in the application from lua files. The trigger for the lua code is from within the application though.
Yes, sorry, was responding to one thing and noting another

As someone who has absolutely no expertise on Neovim core development (but is a daily user of Neovim) I definitely see Neovim as more of a text editor than a tabular editor. That said, I do have uses for such a thing. For example, my plugin [`nvim-typora`](https://github.com/Iron-E/nvim-typora) has some tabular arrangement functionality that could work really well if given the possibility of rendering tables specially instead of with text.

For example, instead of this raw rendering of a table:

![cap](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36409591/109198371-26704f80-776c-11eb-83f4-1d4e40ef33b0.png)

Show an editable tabular view (excuse the poor photoshopping):

![cap](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36409591/109198675-81a24200-776c-11eb-9b98-b709a4b0e0ce.png)

How feasible would it be to create an external UI for such a thing on top of Neovim, do you think?

For a plugin, I would say embed a floating window over where you wanted the spreadsheet to be inserted, and use `:term` to ineract with sc-im. Since it has no remote support, and uses ncurses, it would require sc-im to have substantial rewrites for anything more advanced (having the ability to send commands from neovim to sc-im for example)

I think that could definitely work! Use a command to extract the table to a temporary file, float a terminal with `sc-im` over it, read the temp file back into the buffer after closing.

Need to read some into callbacks with the terminal but I definitely see it.

@Iron-E @mjlbach ``sc-im`` provides ``--nocurses`` option to perform operations without opening a TUI. It doesn't keep a live session (I mean it doesn't start a server), so it's not like a remote control, but one can use it evaluate results without curses TUI.

I think this would make an excellent plugin and hopefully the information here will be sufficient for someone to implement it, but this is out of scope for core. We have a new [discourse](https://neovim.discourse.group) instance with a plugin-development section that would be a good candidate for additional discussion if you need help.

for future googlers, the plugin is implemented at least once:
https://github.com/DAmesberger/sc-im.nvim

title: Integrate sc-im into neovim
